title: (x) Serif face on Aurelie Sheehan's "History Lesson for Girls" book cover - New Clear Era {Jan}
content:
I realise this may be a long shot as the type is quite small. Unfortunately I couldn't find any bigger versions of [this cover](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209040726/http:/bookcoverarchive.com/book/history_lesson_for_girls). Maybe the one-storey "a", peculiar "y", and swash on the capital "G" (the descending "F" may very well be a customisation) rings a bell with someone who knows what this one is.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209040726im_/http:/typophile.com/files/history_lesson_for_girls_4081.large.jpg)
author: Bald Condensed

comments.content:
I am probably very-very off track here but tome it looks like someone took y and G from a Goudy Modern Italic and straightened them.

But I am probably totally wrong.
It's a very interesting theory, but straightening an italic face is so destructive for the general architecture of the characters that it would show in the curves and so on.

Doesn’t ring a bell. Looks like it could have been inspired by [FF Disturbance](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209040726/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/downloads/fontfont/ff_disturbance_ot/?&sample_text=History%20Lesson%20for%20Girls%20fi%20fl), no? The G with swashy descender, the long f (note Jeremy Tankard’s f ligs) …

[New Clear Era from fontBoy](http://web.archive.org/web/20100209040726/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/fontboy/new-clear-era/).

Mike’s Serif Font Identification Guide worked like a charme.

Jan! You saved my bacon! Twice! :^)

Thanks, you're reliable as always. ;)
